displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. You have. Doctor: Because we did it before the testosterone, during the testosterone, during the enzalutamide, and we try to look at how those treatments affect it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I’ll, I’ll find out. Patient: Alright. Doctor: So- Family Member: I wanted, I want your input, uh but we couldn’t just give him that - because he is all at that level of three injections of testosterone, he’s a perfect candidate just for that immune thing just to see? (Beeping) Doctor: Well, the immune thing is normally I, I don’t. We’re not allowed to give anything unless it’s in a disease where it’s been approved- Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: because the cost is so very high, the hospital won’t let us do anything. So normally what we have to do is go through the insurance company, tell them what we wanted to do, they deny it, you write letters. So it’s not something that I can just do it tomorrow. Family Member: So you can’t ask-? Doctor: Now you, you know, who have, you’re a person of means, that maybe you could just pay for it, but I haven’t really, I don’t know what the avenue is to do that. (Laughs) Family Member: Well-

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay because too many changes if the pills don’t match well together. Patient: Well I wouldn’t take them all at one time nowhere, if I take my other pill then I wait another hour and then I take that. Doctor: Okay. Well you definitely cannot take the Ambien and the Restoril together. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Are you going to remember that? Patient: Don’t take the Ambien and the who again? Doctor: Restoril. This new sleeping pill. If I give you that… You know what, next time just bring all your Ambien pills and all that. Patient: Okay. I sure will. Doctor: That way, then I will give you the new sleeping pill prescription. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Okay but what I do in the meantime (laughs)

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: and see where things are at. Okay? That way I’ll be able to see if we need to put you back on the medication. Family Member: I think that’s a good idea. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: But that’s not a crutch either to say I’m back on Metformin I can eat cookies. Patient: Oh, oh… Family Member: Because I buy sugar free cookies every now and then. Doctor: Okay. Yeah. Family Member: He’s not doing bad because I’ve seen him worse. Doctor: This is much better than Family Member: Yeah Doctor: what we started off in. He was, you were mighty sick when we started so.

Patient: Okay, would that be your recommendation, to do more hormonal? Doctor: Well, I was gonna, I was gonna talk to you about that. Um… Patient: Right. Doctor: I think it it probably - some type of hormone therapy is probably gonna be in your near future. It might not be the immediate future, but I think sooner rather than later given that we’ve tried this sort of outside-the-box non-hormonal type of therapy and it hasn’t really you know worked as well as we had hoped, the next step I think given that the PSA is rising and given that this lymph node is increasing, I do happen to believe it’s prostate cancer would lead me to the conclusion that hormone therapy is probably the next best thing to do. Patient: Now with hormonal therapy, um it is not a cure. It’s just a uh–. Doctor: That’s correct… It’s - Patient: Okay, so it’s not a cure. The only thing it would be doing is slowing down the progress of the, it would slow down the - Family Member: No. Aggression. Patient: The aggression. Yeah. Family Member: Aggression. Doctor: Right. I wouldn’t say it’s the only thing that it’s doing because that’s doing a lot already. Patient: Uh,hum. Doctor: It’s not just slowing the progression. It is actually killing cancer that’s already there as well. So it is actively killing cancer and starving it of testosterone. You are correct in the sense that um we don’t think that this hormone therapy can eradicate all the cancer leading to a cure so that if you stopped the therapy the cancer would not come back. So we do think that it’s a very, very good treatment that reduces remissions, causes remissions –

Patient: Sure. So you can concentrate. Doctor: So uh you’re still taking the Bicalutamide or have you finished that -- the Casodex? Patient: What is that? Doctor: Uh what the pill that you took two weeks before I gave you the shot. Family Member: Yes, that’s done. The hormone - Patient: Yeah, yeah, that’s - Doctor: Then you’re taking Vitamin D, a thousand units a day. Patient: Doing that. Doctor: And uh so (_-pine name of drug) Patient: Yes. Doctor: And it looks like it’s working and then Oxybutynin for bladder spasms. Patient: Okay, I had - I had some urinary infection, and they gave me seven days’ uh -

Patient: Okay…
DOC Everything else will improve if you start to eat. I think he got that medicine that he gave me, your husband gave me… Doctor: Yep. Patient: I think it got some refills and I think I got about two more refills. Doctor: Good. Patient: But I’ve been taking it though. Doctor: Perfect. Patient: Yep I’ve been taking it. Yep I have been taking it. Patient: Are you gonna give me the sixty OxyContin? Doctor: Yeah I gave you. One is sixty and then the Percocet is a… Patient: One hundred twenty? Doctor: One hundred twenty. Patient: Okay, last time you gave me OxyContin, you gave me one hundred twenty. Doctor: I know because that was the short acting. That’s what I’m telling you. The short acting OxyContin you had one hundred twenty. This is the long acting.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And if you do go back on that program, which it sounds like you’ve already done on your own. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I would definitely encourage you to check in with your cardiologist if you still have one, just to make sure that he or she agrees with that. Patient: Uh hum, okay. Doctor: Uh that they don’t think that it’s unnecessary from a general medical perspective or from a perspective. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So again, you have my blessing, so to speak, but I would also like a second person’s approval as well. Patient: Right. Doctor: Given the primary care provider who’s known you for a long time Patient: Right. Yeah, share it with my primary care, Dr____. Doctor: Now your PSA level from two weeks ago, I think it was third. Patient: Two months, two weeks, yeah.

Patient: And she started taking this fluorescence. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Are you familiar with that? Doctor: Uh-uh. What does that do? Family Member: Purifies the toxins inside your body. Patient: Detoxes, detoxification. Doctor: Okay. Alright. Family Member: Is that good for him to be taking? Doctor: Yeah. No. You’re on a medicine that interacts with everything known to mankind. XTANDI is, remember we talked about how it’s processed through the liver? So it’d be good if you don’t add on extra stuff that will tax your liver that would make the XTANDI either work less or more. More is not necessarily better, and it might make you have more side effects. Family Member: Have you heard of fluorescence? Doctor: Never heard of it. But in general we try to stay away from too many supplements on drugs like XTANDI because it is a known interactor Family Member: Oh. Oh. It’s not a drug. It’s like a homeopathic. Doctor: of many existing drugs. You have to be careful. Right. But all of those are drugs. They really are.

Family Member: a problem that we’re going out of town? Doctor: When are you going? Family Member: Saturday. Doctor: No. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: No. We won’t, I mean, with the holidays, you know, nothing happens. It’s almost like a, not a for sure. Next week it’s a shutdown, but a lot of places are still not functional- Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: -the first week of January.So, and, that’s, you know, reality is probably mid-January, I would imagine. Patient: Okay, well then… Doctor: Okay? Patient: We are leaving town on the… Family Member: The twelfth. Patient: The twelfth, and we’ll be gone for the twentieth. We’re going to Phoenix then.

Patient: and if I’m at the range with my Glock seventeen… Doctor: Gotcha. Patient: …I shoot the target. Doctor: You’ll get it. I hear ya. Patient: So if it’s - if you know I - it’s just a question. Doctor: Sure, sure. Patient: Is this something that’s possible. Doctor: When we do a scan it only tells us after you have X amount of tumors or cells that have glommed together how big it is. Patient: Mhmm, mhmm. Yep. Doctor: Right? So I can only report out what I see, but if I were to open you up || like that… Patient: Yep. Doctor: …it would show more… Patient: Mhmm.

Patient: Thank you, Yeah thank you. Doctor: So it’s finally actually going in the right direction. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But you will need to continue on the prednisone also which I forgot to ask you are you still on that? Patient: I’m still taking it yeah. Doctor: Perfect so you know the job isn’t done, but once we get more chemo on board you should feel better. But also just pain medicine wise, so what are you taking? Anything right now? Family Member: He’s vaping. Doctor: Okay that’s probably not going to do anything. Right? Patient: Um it gave me a little bit and maybe it’s just a mental thing. Doctor: Mm hmm. Patient: Give a little bit of comfort. Doctor: Um hum. Well and you could do that, but I think there are other true medicines that you could try to kind of knock down the pain.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So it just seems like when we give someone on hormone treatment, two hormone suppressions, it sort of falls off the table, and you, it just magnifies all those symptoms. Not in everybody, but usually I see it more in younger guys like you than I do in, you know, much older guys. Patient: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: So, uh, but I think that would be the easiest thing to do. It’s a pill you take every day. I have a range of responses. I would say, I have a subset of men who respond really well for a long time. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Often, you know, a couple of years. I have another group that respond really well, but it’s not very long lived, maybe a couple of months, six months. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then a third group that doesn’t respond at all. Uh, so that would be the easiest thing. That’s a, you know, that’s the prescription. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That, that’s choice one. Choice two would be to give you chemotherapy at this point. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, I think, for me, what I would prefer is to try another hormone pill before we do chemotherapy. Patient: Um hum.

Patient: Sure. Doctor: This will be the same at the left. If there’s any hint of any pain, we just do an x-ray to make sure there’s something that we got to do we’ll worry about it. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: You’re getting treated. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And it’s working. Patient: So fundamentally… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: …as long as I don’t have pain, Doctor: Right. Patient: As long as again the PSA is… Doctor: Coming down. Right.

Family Member: I will thank you. Patient: I’m home boarding the dog. (chuckles) Family Member: Daddy, you want to come take care of (says name) Patient: Oh okay. In terms of Doctor: But if he doesn’t he can go. Family Member: Oh, oh, he can? Doctor: Yeah. It’s only those four days. Family Member: OOH! It’s the first of the week of the week that you get it. Doctor: Of the week you get it, I don’t want you on the plane Thursday through Sunday. Patient: Right. Doctor: But the rest of the time you’re free. So you can go on the twenty-sixth. If you go on the eighth you can go; if you have chemo on the eighth you can go. Patient: Well when would my next day? Is it monthly or is it weekly?

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::strongly agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed
Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White
What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

Please feel free to leave any comments a.text_box: The study was interesting, thank you for the study!

displayed_text: Patient: So what I’ve done you dig, I go to the chiropractor and I let him crack it Doctor: Okay. Patient: and all that. You know what I’m saying? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: That feels good. Doctor: You know that’s not my favorite. Patient: I know. Doctor: I think we talked about the chiropractor and when you have stuff in your back it’s probably not the most stable. Patient: I know, I know. Doctor: However, I think this is enough of a signal that that area in the back tells me that it’s a little bit something more than it was. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: That’s the first. The second part is sort of the rest of you and I know W__ wanted to share that too Patient: Yeah.
